content.overview:
Knowing yourself: Who are you and what are you equals knowing yourself. This lesson will help you to identify your personality, personal strengths and interests.

Knowing who and what you are will help you develop your high school plan for academics and extracurricular activities. You will develop your character profile, which will help you create a plan for what you might want to study in high school and college and help you choose the college/university that is the best fit for you.

content.heading: The Reality of College Admissions
content.synopsis: Let’s start learning about different perspectives regarding the reality of College Admissions in the U.S. by watching a short video.

Despite high grades, elite colleges turn away as much as 95% of their applicants.

Read the following article to get a better view of this perspective. A quiz will be provided afterwards to check your understanding.

Students are sending out more college applications than ever AND College applications are becoming more similar and uniform which makes the attempt to apply for multiple schools easier

content.heading: Admissions Rates for International Students
content.instructionListHeader: Follow these step-by-step directions on how to search college acceptance rates for international students and prepare for your next journal entry.
instructionsList:
Follow these step-by-step directions on how to search college acceptance rates for international students and prepare for your next journal entry.

  • choose three colleges/universities to which you are interested in applying/li>
  • The name of the school you choose will be your keyword to search on the internet
  • Please check the site you are going to click on, and make sure it is not an advertisement(Hint: does the address end in .edu?)
  • Where on the home page can you find general information about the school?
  • Where on the home page can you find information on how to apply to the school?
  • Where on the home page can you find information related to international students?

Click on the school website, and explore:

  • Click on “Admissions” on the top left corner
  • Click on “Undergraduate Admissions”
  • Click on “Applying”
  • Click on” Application Overview”
  • Scroll down to the middle of the page and you will see “View the class of 2018 profile”
  • Click on “View the class of 2018 profile”
  • Scroll down the page,

You will find the information such as:

  • Acceptance/Enrollment Summary/Testing/Diversity/Gender
  • Type of Secondary School
  • Geographic Distribution
  • Current Student Profile
  • Important Dates
Click on the school website, and explore:

If you can’t find the answers by exploring the school web page, is there any other method you can use to find out the information you need? (Hint: Is there a phone number or email address of someone you could contact?)

To play the game do the following: Go to "Tools", "Internet Options", find the "Security" tab, select icon “Trusted sites”, press button “Sites”, uncheck “Require server verification”, put “domain linked to” to the textfield before "http://duke.sharpinteract.com" and press “Add”. Restart your computer, return to the game frame and play the three Geography games by clicking on the links provided."

Click on the links and practice learning the names and location of the different states, regions and lakes of the U.S. Practice until you master it.

Happy exploring!
content.synopsis:
Let’s learn a bit about the geography of the U.S. by playing this fun game to learn the names of the various states and where they are located. After you learn the names and location of the states, click on the U. S. regions link to learn about the culture and history of each region. In this game, there are eight regions.  It explains how the geography, politics and history of each region can be quite different.

Now that you have learned about how to find your “best fit” school and how the admissions process works in the U.S., it’s time to start looking for a school that will be the best fit for you!

One of the first steps in finding your best fit school is deciding where you will be most happy. The U.S. is a large country with several different regions. Next, you will have the opportunity to explore the geography of the U.S.

content.heading: Let’s Conduct Online Research by Doing a “Scavenger Hunt”
instructionsList:
Search on the internet using keywords: the regions of U.S.

Use the questions to guide your search.

What are some of the regions in the U.S.?

Search and using keywords: Climates of different U.S. regions

What is the climate characteristic of EACH region?

Think about which climate/weather of the region is the most similar to your home town?

For example:

  • Does it snow?
  • Does it rain a lot?
  • Is it particularly hot in the summer?
  • How do you like the climate? Why, or why not?

Based on your previous search results of the U.S. regional climate:

Which region suits you the best?

In which state of the region would you like to live?

Search for some different aspects of the region using the region or state as keywords (for example: Northeast or New York State)

What is most well known about this state or region?

What are some unique characteristics about the state?

Look for some unique cultural nuances of this state or region such as style of dress, type of music or dress in this region.

Is this region known for a particular type of food or cuisine?

What are some of the Colleges/universities in this state or region?

Think about which U.S. region you find most interesting.

content.synopsis: There are many people and organizations ready to help you with the college application process such as your school counselor, or an educational consultant. content.heading: The Universal College Application

The Universal College Application (UCA) can help you find and apply for a college/university online. It is designed to save students time and work by submitting the same application to any of the participating schools. UCA is easy to use and does not require an essay or letters of recommendation.

Register on the UCA website, by clicking on the link below and following the instructions. Discover information of the colleges/universities that are right for you at the HOME page. content.heading: Write a First Draft
content.instructionListHeading: Now you will take some time to write the first draft of your essay and upload it to the discussion forum at the beginning of next week to be reviewed by a peer. After you have uploaded your own essay, you will choose another student’s essay and give feedback as though you are an admission’s representative. You will need to remember to follow the discussion forum etiquette and give constructive feedback. You will use any feedback you get from your peers to improve your essay and add it to your journal next week! Before you begin to write your essay, brainstorm some ideas or choose one from The Common Application prompts. Think of topics that will not be covered in other parts of the application. The topic should be compelling and unique to you. If your topic is amusing, that is always an added plus.

You will have this draft completed to be turned in at the beginning of NEXT WEEK to be reviewed by a peer--- this is great practice and something you should continue to do until it is time for you to submit your essay!

content.heading: “Test Optional” Schools
content.instructions: There are now many “test optional” colleges and universities in the U.S. However, the option not to submit tests scores does not apply to international students. The following links are some examples of colleges that are test-optional for American students but have different requirements for international students. As you can see, the test requirements are significantly different from school to school. Look through the following admission sites and make some notes in your journal about what tests they require from international students.
content.synopsis:
Let’s learn a bit about the geography of the U.S. by playing this fun game to learn the names of the various states and where they are located. After you learn the names and location of the states, click on the U. S. regions link to learn about the culture and history of each region. In this game, there are eight regions.  It explains how the geography, politics and history of each region can be quite different.

Now that you have learned about how to find your “best fit” school and how the admissions process works in the U.S., it’s time to start looking for a school that will be the best fit for you!

One of the first steps in finding your best fit school is deciding where you will be most happy. The U.S. is a large country with several different regions. Next, you will have the opportunity to explore the geography of the U.S.

content.heading: Standardized Tests
content.synopsis: The SAT is a globally recognized college admissions test that lets you show colleges/universities what you know and how well you can apply that knowledge. It tests your knowledge of reading, writing and math — subjects that are taught every day in high school classrooms. Most students take the SAT during their junior or senior year of high school, and almost all colleges/universities use the SAT to make admissions decisions.

content.heading: Virtual College/University Tours
content.instructions: Review the following college tour checklist before we begin our virtual college tours. We understand that you cannot answer all of the questions on a virtual tour, but this checklist will start your thinking about what you need to look for as you begin your college tours.

content.heading: University of Michigan Virtual Tour
content.instructions: Take your time looking through the virtual tour of the University of Michigan. This should take about 20 – 30 minutes. While you explore make sure to look at the following : housing options, financial aid for international students, admission policies for international students, student organizations, “Greek Life,” student services, different majors, dining services, career center, events calendar and athletics. Feel free to explore your specific areas of interest.
content.summary: The University of Michigan is a very large, liberal arts university located in the Midwest.

content.heading: Your School List
content.instructionListHeading: Go to the website for each college/university on your School List and take the virtual School Visit to make notes in your journal.
content.instuctionsHeader: Now explore the schools on your School List!  Do any of the colleges/universities on your School List have virtual tours?

instructions: Make notes on your School List with information you learned on your Virtual College visits.

instructionList: Which college/university tour did you enjoy the most?
Did taking these tours change how you feel about the size of the school you are interested in attending?
Which location in the U.S. do you now prefer? Has your research changed your opinion about where you want to attend college/university?
After taking the tours, did you change your mind about the type of school you want to attend? For example, Liberal arts or special focus college/university.
Are athletics or arts programs important to you? If so, do they have the programs you desire?
Is convenient travel to your native country important to you? If so, is the college/university you are looking at easy to get to?
What do you think you would get out of visiting the colleges/universities on your School List?

instructions: Now plan your own college tour to visit the top schools on your School List.
Remember to budget carefully, take into consideration the time it takes to get between colleges, and try not to overbook yourself.
Remember, this should be a fun process for you!

content.synopsis: It is important to decide if you are going to take a college/university visit! Visiting a college/university campus is often the most important information‐gathering tool in the search. It provides an excellent opportunity to determine a college’s fit. The junior year is a good time to begin visiting colleges—if you are ready and interested.
takeaways: How to prepare for a visit by completing the “College Tour Checklist”
The best times to visit colleges and universities and tips for your college/university visit
How to take assigned virtual college tours
How to plan your own College Tour
